sentence: Consumer stocks were mostly lower, with shares of consumer staples companies in the S&P 500 declining about 0.3%.
Shares of consumer discretionary firms in the S&P 500 were down almost 0.5%.

In company news, Home Depot ( HD ) shares were higher Tuesday, overcoming the home-improvement retailer's this morning reporting fiscal Q1 financial results below analyst estimates after raising its forecast for FY14 per-share earnings, citing "robust" May sales.
Net income for the three months ended May 4 rose 12% over year-ago levels to $1.38 billion, or $1.00 per share, up from a $1.23 billion profit during the same quarter last year.

The Q1 results included a $0.04 per share benefit from its sale of an equity stake in HD Supply Holdings, which if deducted from the reported EPS, reduces the company's adjusted earnings to $0.96 per share, lagging the Capital IQ consensus by $0.03 per share.
Total sales rose 3% year over year to $19.69 billion, also coming up about $280 million shy of Wall Street expectations.
Same-store sales rose 2.6% company-wide, HD said, with sales for U.S. stores open one year or more climbing 3.3% over year-ago levels.
"The first quarter was impacted by a slow start to the spring selling season," CEO Frank Blake said in prepared remarks.
"But we had solid results in non-weather impacted markets and expect our sales for the year to grow in line with the guidance we previously provided."
HD raised its outlook for FY14 adjusted earnings, now expecting a 17.6% jump in diluted earnings to $4.42 per share, matching analyst estimates.
It also reaffirmed its full-year sales forecast, predicting 4.8% growth to around $82.59 million, roughly in-line with the Street view looking for $82.65 billion in annual sales.
The company reaffirmed forecasts for fiscal 2014 sales to be up approximately 4.8% from fiscal 2013.
The company raised its fiscal 2014 diluted EPS guidance and now expects diluted EPS to be up approximately 17.6% to $4.42 for the year, in line with Street estimates.
HD shares were up 2.7% at $78.55 apiece in mid-day trade, earlier climbing to an intra-day high of $78.82 a share.
The stock has a 52-week range of $72.21 to $83.20 a share, rising 4.6% over the past 12 months.
(+) TEDU, (+0.1%) Q1 revenue of $24.3 mln beats Capital IQ consensus by around $1.22 mln.
EPS of $0.01 matches projections.
Guides Q2 revenue in-line with analyst expectations for $30.27 mln in revenue, forecasting $30.5 mln to $31.5 mln.
(-) URBN, (-7.9%) Q1 EPS of $0.26 trails analyst projections by $0.01 per share but revenue of $686.3 mln tops FactSet consensus by around $6 mln.
